text:
Extruder blob
=============

The blob (mass of plastic accumulated around the hotend) is one of the most scary-looking printing problems you might face with your 3D printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Removing it after it happens is quite tricky, though not impossible.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We prepared a short video on how to remove an extruder blob.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The video features our Original Prusa MK3, but the same principles of heating the filament blob in order to soften it and carefully removing it with pliers apply to all our FDM printer models.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 1. Preheat the nozzle in the _LCD Menu -> Settings/Control -> Temperature -> Nozzle_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The temperature needs to be approximately 30°C higher than the temperature at which the blob has formed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
For example, if the blob is made of:
   
   * PLA: preheat to 250°C
   * ABS/PETG: preheat to 280°C

2.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If MINTEMP or Preheat error message appears on the LCD, it means the thermistor or the heater cable (respectively) is already broken.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In this case, your only option is to use a heat gun to heat the plastic.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Work very carefully, you don't want to melt the printed parts surrounding the hotend.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Clear the blob little by little.

3.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: After the hotend reaches the right temperature, leave it this way for at least 5 minutes.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: _Turn the printer off before the next step, or you might cause an electrical short.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Smaller blobs will start to fall off by themselves.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: As for the bigger ones, use a pair of pliers to remove the now soft plastic mass from the hotend carefully.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Again, be very cautious around the leads coming from the hot end, in particular, the thermistor leads.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Once the big chunks of the amassed plastic are removed, use a small brass brush to get rid of what's left (as shown in the video above).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In case you do not succeed, as well as in case the blob has damaged some of the extruder parts, you can find your spare parts here.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To see the spare parts section, you have to be logged into the account you used to purchase the printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How to prevent this problem from happening

Unlike the Spaghetti monster issue, the blob issue often occurs early during the print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In general, the blob forms if the first layer detaches from the print surface and sticks to the moving hot nozzle while it keeps extruding, causing the blob to grow.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
In order to prevent this situation from happening, bear in mind these simple rules:

*
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Always make sure to clean the print surface before starting the print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See First layer issues for more details.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: * Take the time to adjust the first layer height at the beginning of the print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that the first layer is sticking properly to the entire print surface.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: * Check the print every now and then.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you observe any potential problem, pause the print and give yourself the time to solve it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: As a last resort, you can always stop the print, adjust the settings, and start again.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Silicone sock

Consider installing a silicone sock.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This is available in our shop for MK4/S, MK3.9/S, and XL.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Although the component does not prevent extruder blobs, in case this occurs, it makes it easier to remove it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Preheat error
=============

The Preheat error message occurs when there is a problem with the preheat process before your print starts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Therefore, there is something preventing the printer from heating up in proper time.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure to distinguish between the Preheat error and the Bed preheat error.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Preheat error - a problem with preheating the hotend.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: * Bed preheat error - a problem with preheating the heatbed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Troubleshooting

Preheat error

1.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that the ambient temperature is stable and there is nothing cooling the printer down, such as a nearby air-conditioning unit or an open window.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 2. Make sure the thermistor and heater are properly plugged into the electronics board.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can doublecheck that by following these guides: Mini RAMBo electronics wiring (MK2S, MK2.5, MK2.5S) or Einsy RAMBo electronics wiring (MK3/MK3S/MK3S+).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 3. Check if the fuses are not blown.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 4. Make sure that your hotend assembly is correct.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the issue persists, then there is something wrong with your printer's thermistor or heater.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In order to find out which one of these two is malfunctioning, perform the simple test described below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Bed preheat error

1.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that the ambient temperature is stable and there is cooling down the printer, such as a nearby air-conditioning unit or an open window.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 2. Make sure the heatbed thermistor is properly seated under the heated bed and secured with the golden Kapton tape.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If not, then simply put it back and make sure that the thermistor cable has some space for movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 3. Make sure that the thermistor and heatbed are correctly plugged into the electronics board.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can doublecheck that by following these guides: Mini RAMBo electronics wiring (MK2S, MK2.5, MK2.5S) RAMBo electronics wiring (MK3/MK3S/MK3S+).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 4.  Check if the fuses are not blown.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the issue persists, there is something wrong with your printer's thermistor or heater.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In order to find out which one of these two is malfunctioning, perform the simple test described below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Testing the thermistor and heater

It is not very common, but there is a chance that only the thermistor is defective.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can check it using the following test:
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 1. Use a hairdryer to blow hot air at the heatbed or hotend.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In the meantime, check if there is any temperature change on the LCD screen.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If there is a positive temperature change it means that the heatbed or hotend thermistor is working.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Which means there is something wrong with the heater or heatbed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In both cases contact our support and they will provide assistance.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If there is no change at all, the hotend or heatbed thermistor is defective.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
First layer issues
==================

This is by far the most common 3D printing problem, and probably the first one you may encounter.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The first layer is the essential one because it is the base of the printed object.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Therefore, if it isn’t perfect, the chance of print failure increases.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Many common 3D printing problems stem from a poor first layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: There are a couple of things that can go wrong when printing your first layer, so let’s take a look at what can be done to avoid these problems.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The print surface should be regularly maintained to achieve optimal printing quality and minimize the chance of failed prints.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It's an easy procedure, so let's take a look at our tips and recommendations.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How to prepare your print surface

If you don't touch the print surface with your hands or dirty tools, then you don't have to clean it before every print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Clean your tools the same way you would the bed, and you will be able to start your next print right away.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Isopropyl alcohol - smooth, satin, textured sheets

To achieve the best adhesion of the print surface, it is vital to keep it clean.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The best option when printing with ABS, PLA, and many other materials is 90% Isopropyl alcohol, which can usually be sourced locally at drugstores or hardware stores.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Denatured alcohol is also an option.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We recommend always using 90% IPA.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Solutions with lower percentages may contain unsuitable chemicals and oils.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: PETG, ABS, ASA, XT, and CPH filaments are an exception - the adhesion may be too strong, and you can damage your Smooth PEI sheet.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We recommend using a separating agent (e.g. a glue stick).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For more information on how to print with these materials, check out our Material guides.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Dish soap and water

If the adhesion seems to decrease over time even when using IPA, you can clean the steel sheet with a few drops of dish soap and warm water (not hot!).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This should not be done often, and do not submerge the sheet completely in hot water, but it will dissolve some oils and sugars that gather over time and that IPA does not remove.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure to use only dish soap and dry the sheet well before using it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Acetone

PEI can lose its adhesive powers after a couple of hundred hours.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When you see models coming loose regularly, wipe the surface thoroughly with acetone to restore the adhesion.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This should only be used in the smooth PEI sheet and only around once per month.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Do not overuse acetone.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Extended use makes PEI surface brittle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, do not use acetone before printing with PETG.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Glue

Glue is a great, easy-to-use tool to increase adhesion.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It also creates a protective separation layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: No need for glue specially made for 3D printing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can use a basic (PVA-based) glue stick.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
From our experience, it is not needed when printing PLA, but may it be advisable when printing:

* Polyamide (Nylon)
* PETG
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Polycarbonate (PC)
* PET-based materials
* ABS
* ASA
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Other more exotic materials
* Flexible materials

Other types of glue should not be used as a substitute.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Don't put Superglue on your sheet!
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When removing prints with a large surface area, you may have to assist the process using a spatula.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Be gentle when flexing the sheet and removing the print as the smooth PEI foil can tear.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Resurface it

It can happen that you will leave some small marks on the print surface with your nozzle or tools.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Typically, they will be shinier than the rest of the pad.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It does not affect functionality or adhesion.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: However, if you want to have the same surface look on the whole print bed, you can resurface it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The easiest way is to take the hard side of a dry kitchen sponge and gently wipe the affected area in a circular motion a few times.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Another option is to use fine-grit sandpaper (400-600) and lightly give the sheet a rub.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Wipe over with IPA after doing so.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: | Smooth PEI sheet                    | *
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Isopropyl alcohol 90%+ (IPA) -best degreaser
* Warm water + few drops with
dish soap (in case IPA doesn’t
remove sugar residue on the
sheet)
* Acetone - once in a while to
rejuvenate the sheet | Use glue stick when printing FLEX, PETG, and other PET-based materials, as well as ABS and ASA.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: IPA + PETG will cause the print to adhere very strongly to the sheet.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Removing it could be extremely difficult.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
| Textured powder-coated
sheet | *
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Isopropyl alcohol 90%+ (IPA) -
best degreaser | Never use acetone!
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
|
| Satin powder-coated sheet           | *
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Isopropyl alcohol 90%+ (IPA) -
best degreaser | Never use acetone!
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
|

Special print sheets

For print sheets that are NOT smooth, satin, or textured, the surface preparation procedure can differ from sheet to sheet.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Follow the procedures outlined in their dedicated articles.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
* Special PA Nylon steel sheet](http://help.prusa3d.com/article/special-pa-nylon-steel-sheet_341570)
* PP steel sheet

The nozzle is too close/far from the sheet (MK2/S, MK2.5/S, MK3/S/+, MK3.5/S)

If the nozzle is too close to the printing bed, there won’t be enough room for the plastic to come out of the extruder.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: By having the nozzle too close to the print surface, you will essentially block its opening, so that no plastic can be extruded.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can easily recognize this issue when the printer does not extrude plastic for the first layer or two.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Use the Live Adjust Z function and First Layer Calibration (i3) options to tweak the height of the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You perform the calibration from _LCD Menu –> Calibration –> First layer calibration_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For more information on this procedure, please see the dedicated article First Layer Calibration (i3).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Speed and temperature

Decrease the printing speed

If the steps described above didn’t help, then try decreasing the printing speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The easiest way how to do it is by rotating the knob during the printing process, lowering the percentage.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Counterclockwise = decrease speed, Clockwise = increase speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We suggest decreasing the speed to about 75% for the first three layers, and then returning it to normal.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Use recommended printing temperatures

Make sure to use the recommended nozzle and heatbed temperatures.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: PrusaSlicer will configure them correctly based on the selected material, so you don’t need to adjust the temperatures manually on the printer itself.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you are experimenting with new materials that don’t adhere well, you can try to increase the heatbed temperature by 5-10 °C.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This way the plastic will stick a bit better.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
A full or partial clog

The extruder could be clogged.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This can happen either when excessive debris gets stuck inside the nozzle, when hot plastic is kept inside the extruder for too long, or when the thermal cooling for the extruder is not sufficient and the filament begins to soften outside of the desired melt zone.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Please see our dedicated article Clogged nozzle/hotend (MK3.5/S, MK3S+, MK2.5S).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Uneven surface

If your print surface is not flat and the alignment of the mesh does not help, to achieve a flat print surface, a temporary solution is to add a piece of paper under the uneven area of the steel sheet.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
A more permanent solution would be to perform the firmware Bed Level Correction.

Correctly placed sheet

Before printing, make sure that you have the print plate properly installed, and that there are no leftovers from the previous print or a piece of loose filament that could affect the sheet position.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, make sure that the sheet is straight and not bent or damaged.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Brim

Before you consider applying extra adhesion materials onto the bed, consider using the Brim option in PrusaSlicer, which increases the surface area of the first layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See our dedicated article Skirt and Brim.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Expansion joints (CORE One, MK4/S, MK3.9/S, MK3.5/S)

Having the expansion joints in the wrong orientation can cause an uneven first layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that all of them have the full side facing the center of the carriage.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Nozzle conditions (CORE One, MK4/S, MK3.9/S)
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The nozzle on the Nextruder has to be at the correct height.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you are not sure if the height is correct, open the thumb screws on the side of the heatbreak, and push the nozzle up.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Tighten the thumb screws just by hand, do not use any tools.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you have a Nozzle Adapter, check the installation again to make sure that the nozzle has not been lowered with the installation of the adapter.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Nozzle conditions (XL)

On single-tool XL, after removing the x-carriage cover, hold the heater block (make sure that the nozzle is not heated!), and use the Torx TX8 key as shown in the picture to tighten the set screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Do not use extra force while tightening, it may damage the hotend tube.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The nozzle must be approximately at a 35°-40° angle to avoid damaging the hotend cables.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On multi-tool XL, identify the tool that has the nozzle to be checked, and park it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Hold the heater block (make sure that the nozzle is not heated!), and use the Torx TX8 key in the part shown in the picture to tighten the set screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Do not use extra force while tightening, it may damage the hotend tube.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The nozzle must be approximately at a 35°-40° angle to avoid damaging the hotend cables.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: LoadCell check (CORE One, MK4/S, MK3.9, XL)
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the filament is loaded while the printer is doing the leveling at the start of a print, check if the extruder is not pulling the filament down by loosening the filament spool a little.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you have the filament being fed by a PTFE tube, make sure that the tube is not short.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: After the previous checks, go into the printer menu to _Control -> Calibrations & tests -> Loadcell test_, and make the LoadCell test per screen instructions.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Mechanical checks (XL)

Core XY

If your first layer is showing one side higher than the others on the Original Prusa XL, check the assembly of the Core for any loose screws which hold the Core to the four extrusions.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, use the torque indicator, available for printing in the XL printable parts page, in the _Others_ folder, to make sure the screws are tightened correctly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Heatbed Tiles

Check if any of the screws under each heatbed tiles are loose.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can refer to the heatbed tile replacement guide to access the parts and check them.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Z-axis bearing housing

The Z-axis bearing housings are the end-stop for the Z-axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is important to have a small clearance between the Z-axis bearing housings and the heatbed frame when the printer is at the top position.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This way, during the mesh bed leveling and the autohome procedures, there can be an ideal amount of small contact between the nozzle and the print surface.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Too small of a clearance can cause the Nozzle Cleaning Failed warning message to appear.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In this case, in order to achieve the ideal clearance, slightly loosen the bolts holding the bearing housings in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the warning message still appears, slightly loosen the mentioned bolts once again, keeping in mind to still have the Z-axis bearing housings reasonably tight and held in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Once you find an ideal tightness for the bolts that works and holds the Z-axis bearing housings in place, keep the change permanent.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
The Benchy hull line

When printing the famous 3DBenchy test model, you may notice a horizontal line at the hull’s widest part.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This is not a print defect but rather a feature of the model itself.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The line represents the waterline of the boat.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is intentionally modeled into the 3D file.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Therefore, you do not need to troubleshoot your printer or slicer settings if you observe this line.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Layer shifting

Layer shifting occurs when one layer is printed offset relative to the previous one.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This results in the whole upper part of the print being shifted.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It can happen in one or both axes.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Common causes

- Loose or misaligned belts
- Obstructions on the print bed
- Stepper motor driver overheating
- Printer frame or axis components not tightened properly

Fixes

- Check and tighten belts
- Remove any obstructions
- Improve cooling for the stepper drivers
- Verify mechanical assembly and re-tighten screws if necessary

SD cards and USB drives

Sometimes print issues originate from corrupted or incompatible SD cards / USB drives.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Tips

- Always format cards in FAT32 before using them with your printer.
- Avoid cheap or unbranded cards; use quality brands.
- If you experience random print failures, try another card or drive.
- Safely eject cards from your computer to prevent corruption.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Extruder blob

An extruder blob, also called a “blob of doom,” is a large accumulation of filament around the nozzle and hotend.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It happens when a print detaches from the bed and sticks to the nozzle instead.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Prevention

- Ensure proper first layer adhesion (clean bed, correct Z-offset).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
- Use adhesives like glue stick if needed.
- Check filament path is not obstructed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Fix

- Carefully heat the nozzle to soften the blob.
- Remove material with pliers or tweezers.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Inspect hotend for damage before resuming prints.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Layer shifting
==============

Layer shifting is a printing issue that causes the layers of the printed object to shift from their intended positions.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is usually associated with an abnormal movement of the X-axis and/or the Y-axis, leading the extruder head to be misaligned mid-printing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In order to troubleshoot the issue correctly, it is crucial to recognize in which axis the layers shifted.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See the three photos below demonstrating three different kinds of layer shifts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Troubleshooting is the same for both axes.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Layer shifts are most often caused by the wrong tension of the belts or pulleys not being secure.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Prusa CORE One

Check your printer’s power mode
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Run the printer in normal mode rather than in the stealth mode.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can change the power mode in _LCD Menu -> Settings_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The stealth mode is perfect for small and simple objects.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For bigger or more complex prints, the normal mode is recommended.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check the XY axes movement and the belt tension

Test movements both from the printer menu (_LCD Menu -> Control -> Move Axis_), and with the printer cold and off, by hand.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When testing the movements by hand, test both movements along the X and Y axes, and also along both diagonals.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: While an inconsistency in X or Y axis movement is most likely related to the belt tension, an inconsistent diagonal movement is related to the motor that controls that diagonal, or the pulley attached to it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To check and adjust the belt tension, follow the guidelines from the dedicated belt adjustment guide.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When adjusting the belt tension, do not lose alignment of the CoreXY.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check your X/Y axis motors and pulleys

If one of the motor pulleys loosens over time, it will misalign and contribute to inconsistent movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulleys are positioned differently on each of the two XY motors.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Each motor pulley has two set screws, one of which has to be aligned with the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Looking from the front of the printer: 

* Left 
  
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are above the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Right
  
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are below the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa MK-series

Check your printer’s power mode
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Run the printer in normal mode rather than in the stealth mode.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can change the power mode in _LCD Menu -> Settings._
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The stealth mode is perfect for small and simple objects.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For bigger or more complex prints, the normal mode is recommended.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, note that in stealth mode, the Crash detection feature is not available.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Make sure the extruder and the heatbed can move freely

Make sure there are no obstructions in the path of the extruder or heatbed and their bearings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For example, there might be a piece of filament stuck around the belt (usually around the Y-axis pulley) from your previous prints.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Another instance of obstruction is when the zip ties, or other parts of the extruder cable bundle, are not optimally positioned as indicated in their respective assembly guide.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the cables hit the frame before the extruder assembly (MK3 and higher) or before the X end-stop (on MK2/S or MK2.5) the printer detects an inaccurate end position.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See the photo below and make sure the cables are arranged accordingly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Verify if the smooth rods don't bear any deep scratches and if the bearings are properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Clean the smooth rods with a clean paper towel before applying lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The optimal lubricant is our Prusa Lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A lithium-based, general-purpose grease also works well.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check your X/Y axis motors and pulleys

Make sure the X and Y motors are tightened in the motor mount, that the pulley is secured on the motor shaft and aligned with the pulley on the opposite end, and that the pulley can move freely.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both grub screws need to be tight, one of them has to be tightened against the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A loose or misaligned pulley is usually the main cause of staircase layer shifts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both pulleys on both axes also have to be aligned, meaning the motor pulley has to be well centered and the belt has to be moving in a straight line, not traveling from right to left while the pulley is turning.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check the tension of your belts

Check your belt tension.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On MK-series printers, a quick way to check it is using our belt tuner, with the instructions in the video below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On MK3/S/+, it is possible to check the Belt Status numbers via _LCD Menu -> Support -> Belt Status_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: While there is not a precise ideal value, from our experience, the best approximate value is around 250 on the X-axis, and 275 on the Y-axis, with an optimal range at +-15 from these values on either axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The value does not represent a physical quantity, but an arbitrary number inversely proportional to the motor load.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The values are with the consideration that the assembly is good and that the parts are in good condition and properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Values may not be accurate if there are other problems.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
If your value is under (or close to) 240, you need to loosen the belt
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
If your value is over (or close to) 290, you need to tighten the belt
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The values are updated every time you run the Selftest or run the belt test in _LCD menu -> Calibration -> Belt test_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Other MK-series models do not have the belt status option.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The clue we can give you is that the belt should sound roughly like a low bass string when plucked.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
It should be possible to pinch the two sides together with your thumb and index finger, but you should feel a little bit of resistance.

!
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The plastic parts holding the belts can get loose over time.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Use the following technique to test if the pulley is correctly tightened and if the belt is not too loose.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Hold the X-axis motor shaft with pliers (take advantage of the flat part of the shaft) and try to move with the extruder.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The same procedure can be applied to test the Y-axis pulley and belt.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: There should be no slack from the belt or any axis movement during the procedure, if there is, then the belt is too loose.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa MINI/+

Check your printer’s speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When printing large objects, it’s recommended to decrease the printing speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: During a print, go to _LCD Menu -> Tune -> Speed_ and decrease the number.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check the X/Y belts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that belts are properly tightened.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A quick to check this aspect is using our belt tuner, with the instructions in the video below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Belts should be tight enough to sound like a low bass note when plucked.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the belts are loose, tighten them first: first, loosen the two screws as depicted below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Then, tighten the two screws at the very end of the X-axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: They go directly against the metal rods, so the more tightened they are, the further you move the plastic part.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Once you are done, tighten the first two screws again to fix the part in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check X/Y axis pulleys.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both pulleys on both axes also have to be aligned, meaning the motor pulley has to be well centered and the belt should be perfectly straight.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check whether the X-axis belt is not brushing against printed parts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure nothing is blocking the movement of your axis – Check for any obstructions in the path of the bearings or any possible waste from previous printings stuck around the belt (usually around the Y-axis pulley).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Loose X/Y-axis belt pulley

If the set-screw on the belt pulley has come loose or it was not secured on the flat side of the motor shaft, it can slip and may cause issues with the axis not moving perfectly in tandem with the motor's rotation.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The set-screw for the Y-axis is easily accessed, being under the bed, but the X-axis is a bit more tricky.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can access the set-screw for the X-axis through a hole on the top of the extruder (picture below).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You will not be able to see if the set screw is aligned with the flat side of the motor-rod and tightening it will only be a temporary fix, but it is a great way of knowing if this is the issue and what needs to be disassembled.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you only see shiny metal in the hole, you must rotate the motor to reveal the set-screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Even it is loose, it will move a little with the rotation of the motor, revealing the screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Access Settings -> Move Axis -> Move X, on the LCD-menu, and rotate the knob to spin the motor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Free movement of the axis

Make sure the print head (the part moving along the X-axis) can move freely in the entire range.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Especially the cable bundle attached to the extruder should not prevent the print head from reaching the end of the axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, verify if the smooth rods are not scratched and if the bearings are properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Clean the smooth rods with a clean paper towel before applying lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The optimal lubricant is our Prusa Lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A lithium-based, general-purpose grease also works well.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa XL

Belt tension

Using the guidelines in the dedicated article, check the belt tension.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Ensure that the belt clamps are in good visible status.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To access them, remove the front cover and check the clamps for visual damage.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
XY motor pulleys

Though rare, if one of the motor pulleys loosens over time, it will misalign and contribute to inconsistent movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulleys are positioned differently on each of the two XY motors.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
* Left
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Note the orientation of the pulley.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are below the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulley is 2.5mm higher than the start of the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Use the 2.5mm Allen key for reference.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Alternatively, measure the distance between the beginning of the motor shaft and the pulley, 3.6mm.
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Right
:LABEL: Sentence

text: * Note the orientation of the pulley.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are above the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulley is flush with the top edge of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Print geometry and settings

Objects with overhangs are generally harder to print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Some overhangs might even warp upwards during the print, and the nozzle might crash into them.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The same can happen in some cases if you choose a very small infill percentage when slicing the 3D model.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To prevent printing overhangs, you can cut the object (check out our article on the Cut tool).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can also try to increase the print fan speed or increase the retraction length in PrusaSlicer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Print fan speed is found in _Filament settings -> Cooling_ and retraction length in _Printer Settings -> Extruder 1._
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
MINTEMP error and MINTEMP BED
=============================

The MINTEMP error (written sometimes as min temp) occurs when the temperature readout from the heatbed thermistor or hotend thermistor drops below a certain amount within a certain time frame.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is a safety feature that prevents the printer from overheating in case of a faulty thermistor because, by default, the printer is set to balance out any heat loss by pumping more power into the heat bed or hotend heater cartridge.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: MK2/S & MK2.5/S
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Due to the hardware design of the MiniRAMBo and accounting for manufacturing tolerances, there is a temperature below which the thermistors are unable to read reliable values:

- Hotend thermistor - temperatures below 22 °C (71.6 °F)

- Heatbed thermistor - temperatures below 15 °C (59 °F)
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For safety reasons, the MINTEMP error is triggered in case the measured temperatures are below these limits.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This is for the firmware to accurately detect a damaged or disconnected thermistor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For a technical explanation of this limitation, please see this Github issue.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
MK3 & MK3S & MK3S+

The EinsyRambo board of the MK3/S/+ was allowed by its improved thermistor circuitry design to have a wider range of scale when it comes to temperature (thermistor) readings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It also has an onboard thermistor for ambient temperature.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This has allowed the firmware to allow for a lower temperature threshold than on the previous generation (MiniRAMBo).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Hotend thermistor - temperatures below 10 °C (50 °F)
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Heatbed thermistor - temperatures below 10 °C (50 °F)

Also, printing in very cold environments, outside of the recommended operational temperature, can have negative effects due to other factors than the printer's electronics, like material properties.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: What does it look like?
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When one of the thermistor cables is broken, it can be observed when the temperature on the LCD screen starts randomly jumping up and down during the Y-axis or X-axis movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is important to distinguish between the MINTEMP error and the MINTEMP BED error.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
MINTEMP HOTEND/BED fixed

If the cable regains a proper connection and a correct reading from the thermistor, the printer will update the error to "MINTEMP fixed" or "MINTEMP fixed", followed by "Please restart".
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This does not mean the issue is permanently resolved.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You should continue the troubleshooting described in this article.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Testing the thermistor

You can also test it with a multimeter (our article Multimeter usage can guide you).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If it fails to read the resistance on the metal inserts in the jumper connectors, then the wire is broken.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
At room temperature, it should have a resistance you can expect resistance of 80 kΩ - 125 kΩ.

RAMBo board connector

That the RAMBo is the cause is highly unlikely, as the board would not pass the final testing that we do in our factory.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: However, try switching the Hotend and Heatbed thermistors on the board (both have 3 pins), if the MINTEMP does not turn into MINTEMP BED or if the MINTEMP BED does not turn into MINTEMP, the electronics board connector is broken and a new board is needed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You should also notice the temperature reading on the LCD change.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To find the thermistor see Mini RAMBo electronics wiring (MK2S, MK2.5, MK2.5S) or Einsy RAMBo electronics wiring (MK3/MK3S/MK3S+), depending on your printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Wiggle it!
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you do not have a multimeter, a good way to test the cable of the thermistor is to simply wiggle it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Pre-heat to PLA (215/60) and move the extruder or bed by hand, all the way to the end of each side.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See if there is any great change in temperature-reading on the LCD (tens of degrees or zeroing out).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Grab the textile sleeve and manipulate and wiggle it, again checking if there is any change in temperature.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If there is, it indicates a microfracture of the cable when the connection changes depending on orientation.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You then need to replace the thermistor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How to fix it

Temperature

Make sure the temperature of the room where you operate the printer is not below 20 ° C (happens easily if you keep the printer in a basement during winter).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also make sure the printer is not placed next to an opened window, air conditioning, or in a way of a breeze that might cause a sudden temperature fluctuation.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the issue is only caused by the ambient temperature of the room, you can use a hairdryer on the bed / hotend until it reaches a temperature above 18C to initiate a print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: However, some materials, like ASA / ABS, may misbehave if printed in a cold ambient temperature without an enclosure.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Glitch

As mentioned above, the error might have been triggered by a simple glitch.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Try to reset your printer by pressing the X button under the knob and see if it will print afterward.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Thermistor connection

Check if the thermistor is properly connected to the RAMBo board: there is a latch on the connector that needs to snap in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To find the thermistor see Mini RAMBo electronics wiring (MK2S, MK2.5, MK2.5S) or Einsy RAMBo electronics wiring (MK3/MK3S/MK3S+), depending on your printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, make sure the textile sleeve protection of the extruder cable bundle did not snap and that it is still protecting the cables, especially around the spot where they enter the electronics casing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Hotend thermistor

At the other end of the hotend thermistor cable, inspect the wire where it goes into the heater block.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This point is fragile and can get damaged.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Heat bed thermistor

As for the heat bed thermistor cable, make sure it is firmly attached to the underside of the heated bed with the golden Kapton tape.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If not, try to press it back on.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that the thermistor cable has some slack, as shown in the right picture below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is also important that it is not being pinched by the printed cable cover when put together.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This is so it won't be worn down by the movement of the bed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Replacement
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In case there is visible damage on the cable, or if it behaves erratically, the thermistor must be replaced.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can follow our guides How to replace a heatbed thermistor (MK3S+/MK3S/MK2.5S/MK2S) or How to replace a hotend thermistor (MK2S).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Troubleshooting

Stringing and oozing

Stringing or oozing, also known as "hairy prints", is the name given for when small strings of filament are left on a printed model.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This usually happens when the filament keeps flowing from the nozzle while the extruder is moving to another object.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can see this as a marginal line of filament left between the objects.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This issue is caused by very high printing temperatures and/or using incorrect retraction settings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This can be solved by changing a couple of settings in PrusaSlicer and checking your hardware.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Stringing from material left on the nozzle

If you print for a long time from a single type of filament, such as PET-G, the filament can create a thin layer in the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This can cause stringing as the strands of the filament stick to the surface of the print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Therefore, thoroughly clean the nozzle before printing and make sure that any dirt or remnants of previous filaments are removed from the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We highly recommend using our official (factory default) preset settings in PrusaSlicer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: However, if you are printing with your own settings, make sure that you have the retraction settings configured correctly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
PrusaSlicer settings

You should start by checking a parameter known as Retraction.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: What does retraction do?
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When the extruder has finished printing one section/object of your g-code, the filament is pulled back into the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Once the extruder moves to the next location the printing process continues – the filament is pushed back out and it starts extruding from the nozzle again.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Retraction settings can be found in Printer Settings → Extruder 1.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Flexible filaments usually need longer retractions, because the material stretches while being pulled back to the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Flexible materials are a special case and can need a lot of tweaking and tuning.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Retraction settings

- Retraction length: Amount that the filament is pulled back when a retraction is triggered.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
On the MK2.5/S and MK3/S/+, the retraction length should be a maximum of 2 mm.
-
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Due to the Bowden extruder, the retraction length of the Original Prusa MINI/MINI+ presets are much longer (default 3.2 mm).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Lift Z: Lifts the extruder during movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Having this setting lower will improve stringing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Note that disabling this feature may cause the nozzle to hit the printed part.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Retraction speed: Extruder motor speed on retraction.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A higher value improves stringing, but if it is too high it may skip steps in the motor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Minimum travel after retraction: Amount of move that will trigger a retraction (mm).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The preset number in PrusaSlicer is 1 mm, which is a low amount.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Having this number higher will get lower printing times, but increase oozing and stringing.
- Retract on layer change:
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Activates retraction when the layer changes to the next one.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is recommended to leave this option on.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Wipe while retracting: Moves the nozzle (wipe) while the retraction is happening.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
It is recommended to leave this option on.
- Retract amount before wiping: This option does a quick retract before doing the wiping movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: More suitable for the Original Prusa MINI/MINI+.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Other settings that affect retraction

- Only retract when crossing perimeters *(Print settings → Infill → Advanced)*: Disables retraction when the travel path does not exceed the upper layer's perimeter.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Any oozing that happens will be within the walls and should be invisible.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: - Avoid crossing perimeters *(Print settings → Layers and perimeters → Quality)*: Optimize travel moves in order to minimize the crossing of perimeters.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
This will lower the stringing amount, especially in the MINI/MINI+.
- Sequential printing *(Print settings → Output options → Sequential printing)*: Printing each object individually has a smaller chance of causing stringing between the parts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
When using this feature, PrusaSlicer will warn you of any possibility of the extruder colliding with an already printed part, but follow the print closely.
- Nozzle temperature *(Filament settings → Filament → Nozzle)*: Lowering the temperature decreases the occurrence of strings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Try decreasing the nozzle temperature by 5–10 °C and check whether there’s less stringing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Filament

Try using a different spool than the one that is causing the stringing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The filament might have gathered moisture, which will cause a lot of stringing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Hotend

Stringing in the nozzle might be caused by a heat dissipation issue in the nozzle.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Try re‑applying thermal paste on the threads between the heatbreak and the heatsink.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you have recently changed any component in the hotend, it is also possible that some individual parts are not in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Go over the assembly of the hotend and check for any parts that may be different from the instructions.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Enough settings, pass me my heat‑gun!
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you don’t feel like tweaking any of the settings, well, then there is an alternative.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can get rid of the strings with a heat gun (or often with a lighter – but be very careful).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Set your heat‑gun to around 200 °C and aim at the strings for one or two seconds.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This will melt the strings, and the printed object should remain undamaged.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Do not leave the heat source on the printed model for longer than one or two seconds, as this may deform the part.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
The Benchy hull line

The 3DBenchy is a 3D model designed by CreativeTools specifically for testing and benchmarking 3D printers.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: And everyone wants to know, how to print a perfect Benchy.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Ever since it’s release, one specific problem seems to be present, in varying degrees of severity, in all of its prints - the infamous Benchy hull line.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s visible on prints from all FFF printers on the market, cheap or expensive.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s visible no matter the slicing software.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s visible when printing from any material.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s visible even in the Benchy release video from 2015.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Again, in varying degrees of severity - with some combinations of printer, slicer, and material, it can be almost invisible.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Other times, it’s clearly defined, leaving the user disappointed and confused.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: But once you see it, you’ll be able to find it on essentially all of its prints.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The good news is that we managed to mostly eliminate the Benchy hull line in our sample G-codes (not in 100% cases though, more on that later).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can download the G-code here.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The bad news is that the fix isn’t universal.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: And we’re not even sure if such universal fix is physically possible to exist.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A hardware problem?
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When you search for the problem online, you’ll often get an (incorrect) suggestion, that it might be a hardware problem.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
To give you an example, here are some of the suggestions we found online:

- loose belts
- bent Z-axis rods
- irregularity in your z-axis lead screw at that height

If the problem is one thicker line or two thin lines at height of the Benchy’s deck, it’s most likely not a hardware problem with your printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On the other hand, if you get uneven layers from top to bottom, it is most likely a hardware problem (which we’ll not discuss here).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
The culprit

We believe that the main culprit is the sudden transition from sparse infill into full top layers around the 8 mm height (may vary a bit depending on your layer height and number of top layers).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: At this point, there is an abrupt difference in the time a layer takes to print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: And a few layers later, another sudden change happens.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When the deck is finished it’s no longer an almost solid layer, but just a few perimeters again.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Here are the factors that influence the severity of the Benchy hull line:

- Filament material thermal expansion coefficient  
- Print cooling  
- Print environment  
- Other filament properties — dryness, composition

A seemingly similar, yet partly different problem is when printing boxes.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: They also tend to have a line at the height where the bottom solid layers transition into walls.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This has more to do with thin walls, extrusion width, and the material has nowhere to go, but outside.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Our slicer team knows about this problem and it's something that will likely improve in the future.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Why can’t the slicer automatically detect and correct for this?
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s physics.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Plastics, if extruded first from pellets into a filament, and then from filament into a very thin rectangular extrusion, will behave neither as a liquid nor as a solid.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The stretching of the plastic will align the long molecular chains of the polymer, introducing internal stresses to the extrusion.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This internal stress will pull the extrusion together if not cooled quickly enough.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For example, on the MK2 the 3D Benchy has the line more pronounced on the side away from the cooling fan.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It depends on the environment too.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Indeed, as many of you found out, in a cool basement the effects are more pronounced.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The same G-code printed on the same printer with the same filament can have a Benchy hull line in one room and not in the other.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It’s very difficult to automatically compensate for that.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: And to compensate for the internal stresses and cooling effects of the filament.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: One of the reasons being the viscoelastic behavior of the molten plastics, and the dependence of the plastic behavior on its composition, temperature, hydrolysis of the polymer molecular chains.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the filament is not 100% dry (polyesters — PLA & PET are sensitive to hydrolysis, hydrolyzed filament contains shorter polymer chains, thus being less viscous), the effectivity of the cooling, reflections of the cooling air from the already printed objects, etc.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How did we modify the G-code to eliminate it?

Something that helps, is to make a modifier mesh in the shape of the deck.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When aligned at the problematic spot, it can be used to split the hull and the deck.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: They are then printed separately, plus the infill doesn’t fill the entire area all the way to the hull perimeters.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Then there’s the order of elements inside a layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For some reason, we got better results when always printing the deck perimeters first, then infill of the deck and then the rest of the layer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We manually edited this order using a text editor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We’re not sure if it ended up helping, but we also manually edited the G-code in order to slightly lower the flow of solid infill, except for the very top layer (of the deck).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Another thing is to print the perimeters as continuously as possible.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Rather than printing perimeters, then infill and then transitioning to the next layer it’s better to print two (or more) layers of perimeters one right after another.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The printer then can go back and print the infill, again two layers at a time.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: We most likely haven’t discovered all factors and in precisely what ratios they influence the severity of the Benchy hull line.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Still, we wanted to share our findings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you make your own research and tests, let us know of your findings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Layer shifting

Layer shifting is a printing issue that causes the layers of the printed object to shift from their intended positions.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It is usually associated with an abnormal movement of the X-axis and/or the Y-axis, leading the extruder head to be misaligned mid-printing.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In order to troubleshoot the issue correctly, it is crucial to recognize in which axis the layers shifted.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See the three photos below demonstrating three different kinds of layer shifts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Troubleshooting is the same for both axes.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Layer shifts are most often caused by the wrong tension of the belts or pulleys not being secure.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Prusa CORE One

Check your printer’s power mode
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Run the printer in normal mode rather than in the stealth mode.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can change the power mode in _LCD Menu -> Settings_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The stealth mode is perfect for small and simple objects.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For bigger or more complex prints, the normal mode is recommended.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check the XY axes movement and the belt tension

Test movements both from the printer menu (_LCD Menu -> Control -> Move Axis_), and with the printer cold and off, by hand.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When testing the movements by hand, test both movements along the X and Y axes, and also along both diagonals.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: While an inconsistency in X or Y axis movement is most likely related to the belt tension, an inconsistent diagonal movement is related to the motor that controls that diagonal, or the pulley attached to it.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To check and adjust the belt tension, follow the guidelines from the dedicated belt adjustment guide When adjusting the belt tension, do not lose alignment of the CoreXY.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check your X/Y axis motors and pulleys

If one of the motor pulleys loosens over time, it will misalign and contribute to inconsistent movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulleys are positioned differently on each of the two XY motors.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Each motor pulley has two set screws, one of which has to be aligned with the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Looking from the front of the printer: 

* Left 
  
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are above the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Right
  
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are below the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa MK-series

Check your printer’s power mode
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Run the printer in normal mode rather than in the stealth mode.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can change the power mode in _LCD Menu -> Settings._
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The stealth mode is perfect for small and simple objects.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For bigger or more complex prints, the normal mode is recommended.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, note that in stealth mode, the Crash detection feature is not available.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Make sure the extruder and the heatbed can move freely

Make sure there are no obstructions in the path of the extruder or heatbed and their bearings.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For example, there might be a piece of filament stuck around the belt (usually around the Y-axis pulley) from your previous prints.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Another instance of obstruction is when the zip ties, or other parts of the extruder cable bundle, are not optimally positioned as indicated in their respective assembly guide.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the cables hit the frame before the extruder assembly (MK3 and higher) or before the X end-stop (on MK2/S or MK2.5) the printer detects an inaccurate end position.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: See the photo below and make sure the cables are arranged accordingly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Verify if the smooth rods don't bear any deep scratches and if the bearings are properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Clean the smooth rods with a clean paper towel before applying lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The optimal lubricant is our Prusa Lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A lithium-based, general-purpose grease also works well.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check your X/Y axis motors and pulleys

Make sure the X and Y motors are tightened in the motor mount, that the pulley is secured on the motor shaft and aligned with the pulley on the opposite end, and that the pulley can move freely.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both grub screws need to be tight, one of them has to be tightened against the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A loose or misaligned pulley is usually the main cause of staircase layer shifts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both pulleys on both axes also have to be aligned, meaning the motor pulley has to be well centered and the belt has to be moving in a straight line, not traveling from right to left while the pulley is turning.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Check the tension of your belts

Check your belt tension.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On MK-series printers, a quick way to check it is using our belt tuner, with the instructions in the video below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: On MK3/S/+, it is possible to check the Belt Status numbers via _LCD Menu -> Support -> Belt Status_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: While there is not a precise ideal value, from our experience, the best approximate value is around 250 on the X-axis, and 275 on the Y-axis, with an optimal range at +-15 from these values on either axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The value does not represent a physical quantity, but an arbitrary number inversely proportional to the motor load.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The values are with the consideration that the assembly is good and that the parts are in good condition and properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Values may not be accurate if there are other problems.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
If your value is under (or close to) 240, you need to loosen the belt
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
If your value is over (or close to) 290, you need to tighten the belt
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The values are updated every time you run the Selftest or run the belt test in _LCD menu -> Calibration -> Belt test_.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Other MK-series models do not have the belt status option.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The clue we can give you is that the belt should sound roughly like a low bass string when plucked.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It should be possible to pinch the two sides together with your thumb and index finger, but you should feel a little bit of resistance.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Use the following technique to test if the pulley is correctly tightened and if the belt is not too loose.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Hold the X-axis motor shaft with pliers (take advantage of the flat part of the shaft) and try to move with the extruder.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The same procedure can be applied to test the Y-axis pulley and belt.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: There should be no slack from the belt or any axis movement during the procedure, if there is, then the belt is too loose.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa MINI/+

Check your printer’s speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: When printing large objects, it’s recommended to decrease the printing speed.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: During a print, go to _LCD Menu -> Tune -> Speed_ and decrease the number.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check the X/Y belts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure that belts are properly tightened.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A quick to check this aspect is using our belt tuner, with the instructions in the video below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Belts should be tight enough to sound like a low bass note when plucked.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the belts are loose, tighten them first: first, loosen the two screws as depicted below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Then, tighten the two screws at the very end of the X-axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: They go directly against the metal rods, so the more tightened they are, the further you move the plastic part.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Once you are done, tighten the first two screws again to fix the part in place.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check X/Y axis pulleys.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Both pulleys on both axes also have to be aligned, meaning the motor pulley has to be well centered and the belt should be perfectly straight.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Check whether the X-axis belt is not brushing against printed parts.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure nothing is blocking the movement of your axis – Check for any obstructions in the path of the bearings or any possible waste from previous printings stuck around the belt (usually around the Y-axis pulley).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Loose X/Y-axis belt pulley

If the set-screw on the belt pulley has come loose or it was not secured on the flat side of the motor shaft, it can slip and may cause issues with the axis not moving perfectly in tandem with the motor's rotation.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The set-screw for the Y-axis is easily accessed, being under the bed, but the X-axis is a bit more tricky.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can access the set-screw for the X-axis through a hole on the top of the extruder (picture below).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You will not be able to see if the set screw is aligned with the flat side of the motor-rod and tightening it will only be a temporary fix, but it is a great way of knowing if this is the issue and what needs to be disassembled.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If you only see shiny metal in the hole, you must rotate the motor to reveal the set-screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Even it is loose, it will move a little with the rotation of the motor, revealing the screw.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Access _Settings -> Move Axis -> Move X_, on the LCD-menu, and rotate the knob to spin the motor.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Free movement of the axis

Make sure the print head (the part moving along the X-axis) can move freely in the entire range.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Especially the cable bundle attached to the extruder should not prevent the print head from reaching the end of the axis.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Also, verify if the smooth rods are not scratched and if the bearings are properly lubricated.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Clean the smooth rods with a clean paper towel before applying lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The optimal lubricant is our Prusa Lubricant.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A lithium-based, general-purpose grease also works well.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Original Prusa XL

Belt tension

Using the guidelines in the dedicated article, check the belt tension.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Ensure that the belt clamps are in good visible status.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To access them, remove the front cover and check the clamps for visual damage.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
XY motor pulleys

Though rare, if one of the motor pulleys loosens over time, it will misalign and contribute to inconsistent movement.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulleys are positioned differently on each of the two XY motors.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
* Left
  *
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Note the orientation of the pulley.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are below the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulley is 2.5mm higher than the start of the flat part of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Use the 2.5mm Allen key for reference.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Alternatively, measure the distance between the beginning of the motor shaft and the pulley, 3.6mm.
*
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Right
:LABEL: Sentence

text: * Note the orientation of the pulley.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The teeth for the belt are above the set screws.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The pulley is flush with the top edge of the motor shaft.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Print geometry and settings

Objects with overhangs are generally harder to print.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Some overhangs might even warp upwards during the print, and the nozzle might crash into them.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The same can happen in some cases if you choose a very small infill percentage when slicing the 3D model.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To prevent printing overhangs, you can cut the object (check out our article on the Cut tool).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: You can also try to increase the print fan speed or increase the retraction length in PrusaSlicer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Print fan speed is found in _Filament settings -> Cooling_ and retraction length in _Printer Settings -> Extruder 1._
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
SD cards and USB drives
=======================

As there are ways of remotely transferring files and starting prints, an SD card or USB flash drive is the most common and reliable way to get your files to your machine.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Though common and convenient, flash memory is not the most reliable in itself and your storage can be corrupted or fill up without any obvious signs.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Therefore, we have put together a small guide on how to maintain, format, and purchase memory for your Original Prusa printer.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Make sure your SD card is not locked!
:LABEL: Sentence

text: The SD card has a latch on the side.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Before using your SD card, make sure that the latch is not set to the Locked position.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: In case it is locked, you will not be able to save files on the card, and the printer will not be able to open the SD card.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Storage over 32 GB

There is no upper size limit on compatible storage media, but the built-in Windows formatting tool does not support formatting storage media from a size of 32 GB or more to FAT32.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It will only provide the option for exFAT, which is currently not supported by our printers.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: There are similar limitations under various versions of Apple's OSx, where a third-party application must be used to format it correctly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: To format such a drive you need a third-party application, like Rufus, FAT32 format, or EaseUS Partition Master.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Be careful when using such programs so you do not accidentally format the wrong storage media, like your hard drive.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: However, 8-16 GB is more than enough for most use cases, as a G-code file rarely exceeds 100 MB.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: How do I format the USB drive/SD card?
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If your SD card or USB drive is full or if you can't read the content of the drive, but the drive is recognized by windows, most often all you need to do is to format the drive.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How to format on Windows

On Windows, this is very simple.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Locate your USB drive or SD card in my computer, right-click, and choose format.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: A new small window will pop up.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Most of the time you can simply leave everything to default, but the most important thing is that the File System is set to FAT32.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: This and the Volume Label (Name of the drive) is the only thing you want to touch here.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Click Start and your drive will be formatted in a matter of seconds.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If the USB stick will not work even after this procedure, it is either broken or its "partitioning scheme" is set as GPT, which is incorrect.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: It must be set as MBR (Master Boot Record).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: For how to change this, please see Microsoft's official documentation.
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
How to format on Mac

On Mac, it is a few more steps, but still very accessible.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Again, you want to choose FAT32 as your file system, but you also have the option of changing the "partitioning scheme", which should always be MBR (Master Boot Record).
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
Plug the USB drive or SD card into your Mac.
2.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Go to _Applications -> Utilities_ and launch _Disk Utility._
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 3. Click on the icon in the top-left (green arrow) and select "Show All Devices" from the drop-down menu.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Right-click on the USB drive/SD card in the sidebar under "External".
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Select the top entry for your drive, not a partition located below.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Select Erase in the Disk Utility-toolbar (purple arrow).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 6. Enter a name for the formatted disk.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 7. Click on the Format menu and choose MS-DOS (FAT).
:LABEL: Sentence

text: 8. Make sure the Scheme is set to "Master Boot Record".
:LABEL: Sentence

text:
9. Click Erase.
10.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: Your USB drive will now be erased and re-formatted correctly.
:LABEL: Sentence

text: If your SD card is not detected by the printer at all, be sure to check out SD card not working for further information.
:LABEL: Sentence
